title: ğŸŒ¹ Spread the ğŸ’œ for R ğŸ“¦ with valentine::roses()
text:
To get ready, at least in the R world ğŸ˜, for Valentineâ€™s day, Iâ€™ve cooked a little R ğŸ“¦ to spread the love by generating Roses are Red, â€¦ poems about packages using ChatGPT though the openai package.
You can install it with pak::pak("tadascience/valentine") and perhaps it will be released to CRAN in time for Valentineâ€™s day, itâ€™s in the pipeline.
If you are not already set with an OPENAI_API_KEY, see you later in this article, otherwise letâ€™s make some ğŸ¤– poetry ğŸª¶ ğŸ“

valentine::roses("tidyverse")

ğŸŒ¹ Roses are red, ğŸ“¦
âœ¨ tidyverse is my love, ğŸ’•
ğŸ’¡ It makes coding fun, ğŸ¤©
ğŸŒˆ With tidy data, I rise above! ğŸ“Š


You can tweak the prompt that is sent with the hint= argument.

valentine::roses("lubridate", hint = "make it kinky")

Roses are red ğŸŒ¹
Lubridate keeps time in your bed ğŸ•’ğŸ’¤
Date parsing and manipulation so fine ğŸ˜ğŸ’ƒ
It's the R package that sparks a kinky line! ğŸ”¥ğŸ˜‰


Before you can use valentine::roses() you need to be setup with an API key you can get from OpenAI. Once youâ€™re there, click the â€œCreate new secret keyâ€, name it whatever you like:





And then copy the secret key.





â€¦ and store it in your .Renviron file, e.g.Â by using usethis::edit_r_environ()





Restart R, and ğŸ¦†

valentine::roses("data.table")

Roses are ğŸ”´, 
Data.table is ğŸ’ª,
Efficient and ğŸš€,
It's a ğŸ to me!

title: ğŸ“¦ react
tada::verse() poetry
text:
I just received the Thanks, on its way to CRAN email ğŸ“§ about the tada package ğŸ‰, so itâ€™s a good time for a celebration, and what better way to celebrate than with a dash of poetry.
The @dev version gains a verse() function to write poetry about R packages, thanks for the heavy lifting of the mlverse/chattr ğŸ“¦. We try to maintain a @main branch that could be released at any time, and chattr is not yet released. We hope it will be for the spring ğŸŒ¤ï¸ release of tada, but it will be for the meantime available in the @dev branch.





â”€â”€ chattr 


â€¢ Provider: Open AI - Chat Completions


â€¢ Path/URL: https://api.openai.com/v1/chat/completions


â€¢ Model: gpt-3.5-turbo


So letâ€™s dive right in and do some ggplot2 poetry ğŸª¶





For additional fun, we can write some poetry about a random package we discover with tada::pkg_roulette()

tada::pkg_roulette() |> tada::verse()

title: Welcome to the tadaâ¬¢verse
text:
This is the first article for the tadaâ¬¢science blog, so before we deep dive into changing the world, letâ€™s have some fun ğŸ›.
When I linkedined about the You & R upcoming podcast ğŸ™ï¸ back in December, I shared some code on the survey with potential guests.





â€¦ but as Iâ€™m getting ready to launch ğŸš€ soon - more on that shortly ğŸ•¥ ğŸ•¥ ğŸ•— ğŸ•” - I wanted something a bit more fun, so I wrote the pkg_roulette() function this morning and giftwrapped ğŸ it up as the tada package that is on its way to CRAN. Over time, tada will get more tools and will serve as a host for all things tadaâ¬¢science.

library(tada)


  ğŸ‰ğŸ‰                               ğŸ‰ğŸ‰
  ğŸ‰ğŸ‰                               ğŸ‰ğŸ‰
ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰     ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰       ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰     ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰
  ğŸ‰ğŸ‰                ğŸ‰ğŸ‰     ğŸ‰ğŸ‰   ğŸ‰ğŸ‰            ğŸ‰ğŸ‰
  ğŸ‰ğŸ‰          ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰   ğŸ‰ğŸ‰     ğŸ‰ğŸ‰   ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰
  ğŸ‰ğŸ‰  ğŸ‰      ğŸ‰ğŸ‰     ğŸ‰ğŸ‰  ğŸ‰ğŸ‰     ğŸ‰ğŸ‰   ğŸ‰ğŸ‰      ğŸ‰ğŸ‰
   ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰      ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰     ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰     ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰


The pkg_roulette() gives you the time= and n= arguments to control how long the roulette runs and how many packages it shows. It goes increasingly slowly during that time. You can also control the colors it uses with the cols= argument. But you donâ€™t need to, the defaults are fine.

tada is on its way to CRAN, but you donâ€™t need to wait, and you can start using it right now with:

pak::pak("tadascience/tada")

ğŸ’¡ You have ideas to improve it, awesome ğŸ‘ letâ€™s chat about it on github, on linkedin, on X, on bluesky, on mastodon, on threads or however you usually get in touch.
ğŸ¦˜ donâ€™t go too far, Iâ€™ll be back in this blog.

title: snitch
text:
The snitch ğŸ“¦ is one of those weekend experiments. In this particular case, it comes from I donâ€™t know how to use base::trace() and I want a thing that tells me how a particular function is called, so I want to spy on a function.
The name and logo of the package might be because Iâ€™ve started to read the first Harry Potter book to my 6 years old daughter ğŸ§™.
DALL-E gave a decent logo once I removed explicit HP references ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸, i.e.Â â€œa small gold colored spherical object with wingsâ€ instead of â€œthe golden snitchâ€:

Can you make an hexagon logo for an R package called snitch, inspired by a small gold colored spherical object with wings. The package goal is to spy on function calls.

Anyway ğŸ¤–, letâ€™s dive in, you can install it with pak::pak("tadascience/snitch") Iâ€™m not sure at this point this will make its way to CRAN.
The package has snitch::fun() to spy on a function â€¦ (I donâ€™t know how to get the colors in quarto so letâ€™s go with a screenshot). You first get a rule with breadcrumbs of functions that are spyed on, and then their arguments, courtesy of ls.str() :





â€¦ and snitch::pkg() to spy on functions from a package.

suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(dplyr))
snitch::pkg("dplyr", pattern = "^summarise_")

mtcars %>%
  summarise(mean = mean(disp), n = n())

title: January 2024
text: Itâ€™s already time to sunset ğŸŒ… january, so letâ€™s obey the tradition of rounding up what happened on the previous month. Ok this is mostly a motivational tradition at this point, as it has happened exactly zero times in the past, but you gotta start somewhere right ?!

title: January 2024
text:
xeus-r
This has been in the |> line for a while, but we finally were able to announce the initial version of xeus-r and write ğŸ“ about it the Jupyter blog. xeus-r is a Jupyter kernel for R that is, as the name implies, based on the strong foundations of Xeus. Working on bootstrapping this project with the QuantStack team has been a privilege. Our vision is that it is going to open many doors for the intersection of Jupyter and R users. There is still a lot to do, letâ€™s go ğŸš€.

title: January 2024
text:
tadaâ¬¢science
I bought the tadaâ¬¢science domain a while back, but did not do much with it apart from leaving some breadcrumbs ğŸ here and there, but Iâ€™ve now bit the bullet ğŸš„ and dived in to quarto to start structuring the site and this blog. Itâ€™s early days at the time of writing this wrapup, i.e.Â the landing page mostly contain a ğŸ‰ emoji, but what else do you need really, thatâ€™s the best emoji.
Iâ€™ve asked ChatGPT what a tada scientist is, and this is one of this cases where the ğŸ¤– was a bit unimaginative and gave me the typo treatment:

It seems like there might be a typo in your question. Did you mean to ask about a â€œdata scientistâ€? A data scientist is a professional who uses scientific methods, processes, algorithms, and systems to extract knowledge and insights from structured and unstructured data. They often apply their skills in statistics, data analysis, and machine learning to analyze data and generate actionable insights. If this is not what you meant, could you please clarify your question?

â€¦ I would have prefered an hallucination ğŸ’­ in that instance, so I guess we are going to have to invent what is a tadaâ¬¢science, Iâ€™ll expand on that over time, but we can start with a new spin on the practice of data science. Letâ€™s go from tidy data to tada duty ğŸ¤.

title: January 2024
text:
tada ğŸ‰
The tada ğŸ“¦ was born and is currently in the release process ğŸ“ with CRAN. It currently only ships the pkg_roulette() function for a fun and engaging way to discover new R packages. You can find our more (not really) about it in this blog post but if youâ€™re in a rush, here it is again.





This was received with a bit of curiosity and enthusiasm and a drop of â€œis that it?â€ from the community when I posted about it on linkedin and various other socials. I can relate to both the enthusiasm and the frustration, itâ€™s a ğŸ£ package at this point. It will serve as a host for various tools to support the practice of tadaâ¬¢science.

title: January 2024
text:
You & R
One of my commitments for 2024 is the You & R podcast, which I hinted at in this linkedin post. I received many applications through the survey I shared with the post, and I canâ€™t wait to get started and have these conversations. You & R is meant to be people centered safe place where we exchange stories about how we relate to R. Iâ€™ll invite people across() ğŸ˜‰ the spectrum of trajectories. No matter where you Â® in your journey with our favorite data science tool, your story matters, and weâ€™re all in this together. I want to hear and amplify stories about new R users who give us the privilege to hop on board this â›µï¸ with us, as well as more experience R users.
Iâ€™m currently in the process of gearing up ğŸ™ï¸ğŸ§ ğŸ¥ and learning about things ğŸ› ï¸ like riverside, so please bear with my while I upskill and stay tuned ğŸ¶ for more You & R news.

title: January 2024
text:
Bandwidth ğŸ§˜â€â™‚ï¸
There is currently some available bandwidth here, so if you need a tadaâ¬¢scientist to help you with an R thing, please reach out, linkedin is probably your safest bet right now, but Iâ€™m also in other socials ğŸ¦… ğŸ¦‹ ğŸ˜ ğŸ§¶. Iâ€™m confident youâ€™ll find me.

title: January 2024
text:
Never Search Alone
Iâ€™ve enrolled in a Job Search Council following the approach described in the Never Search Alone book ğŸ“–. Although, I would not say Iâ€™m actually job hunting per se, the approach and the group Iâ€™ve joined ğŸ’œ is flexible enough to accommodate the particularities of the tadaâ¬¢science journey. Finding about about Never Search Alone has been a pivotal moment in my transition from my previous work life. As much as fast reading the book front to cover in two days was exciting, actually doing the work with a JSC is another level, I would recommend it to anyone going through a work cross roads moment.
Letâ€™s see how it goes, but Iâ€™ll probably write about how Iâ€™m adapting the NSA approach to my specifics.

title: January 2024
text:
Reading
Iâ€™m committed to step up my reading habits, because there are a lot more things I want to apply my curiosity too. Last month I read Learning To Scale with my reading partner. Thanks again Diane ğŸ‘¸ for the recommendation, and the book. Learning to Lead, Leading to Learn is next on my list on the same theme.





Also finished Unbroken: the Trauma response is never wrong on a totally different topic. The trauma tapes is one of my favourite podcasts and the book goes further.
What Now, with Trevor Noah is an another one of my favourite podcasts, and the episode featuring Kerry Washington is what converted me to sign up to Audible. This is a fascinating story. Next on my Audible queue is Viola Davisâ€™s Finding Me.
On the more technical front, Iâ€™ll go through C++20: the complete guide because there seems to be a lot of interesting new things happening in C++ ğŸ¤“ğŸš€.
